title: Bitcoin to $380K? Analyst Predicts Historic Altseason - These Low-Caps Could 250x by September
text:
A well-known crypto analyst, Chiefy (@0xChiefy), has sparked fresh excitement across X (Twitter) by claiming that a historic altseason is now beginning â€“ and it could turn small investments into life-changing gains.
In a new thread posted just hours ago, Chiefy says weâ€™re entering the next phase of the crypto cycle â€“ the same kind that turned $150 into over $30,000 during the last bull run.
And this time? He believes Bitcoin is on track for a mind-blowing $380,000 targetâ€¦ with low-cap altcoins following close behind.
Why Chiefy Thinks the Time Is Now
According to Chiefy, crypto works in repeating cycles, typically every four years, and theyâ€™re easy to spot once you know what to look for. He says the current setup mirrors previous rallies where Bitcoin gains strength first, then hands the spotlight to altcoins.
Right now, weâ€™re in the phase where Bitcoin dominance starts to drop â€“ and money rotates into low-cap coins. In other words, this is when altseason really begins.
Chiefy made over $100,000 during the last cycle using this strategy. This time around, heâ€™s doubling down on several small-cap tokens he believes could deliver 200x or more in returns by September.

author: Matias Abril
title: Rise in sleep apnea in Hispanic adults
text:
According to a new health study, 14% of Hispanic men and 6% of Hispanic women have sleep apnea.
Researchers are trying to solve this problem.
Dr. Cynthia Pena Orbea is leading the way to help solve a problem in the Hispanic community: sleep disorders.
â€œHas been associated with chronic conditions, such as hypertension and diabetes, and these are associated with heart disease, which is one of the leading causes of death in the Hispanic population,â€ Orbea said.
According to the CDC, about one in three Latino adults sleep less than seven hours. In Orbeaâ€™s study, only 63% of Hispanics who get a referral for a sleep study complete it. Taking action, she opened up the Hispanic Sleep Clinic at Lutheran Hospital, which is part of the Cleveland Clinic.
About 44% of Hispanic patients say communication issues, like language, lead to worse health outcomes.
This new clinic provides bilingual and bicultural services from start to finish.
â€œTheyâ€™re able to feel that provider-patient concordance is very important,â€ Orbea said.
And so far?
â€œThe common comment that I get is they wish they could get this type of service from different specialties,â€ Orbea said.
Now, she plans to continue her research on why the Hispanic community struggles with sleep apnea.
â€œTo talk to different people from urban areas, rural areas, people who have access to health care, people who donâ€™t have access to health care,â€ she said.
By the way, this clinic offers these services to anyone who asks to be seen, not just Hispanics.
The hope is that programs like this will expand in other communities, especially ones with large Hispanic populations.
